required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of IV 10, 20, and 30mg for Renal Colic Pain in the ED
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Intravenous Ketorolac 10, 20, and 30mg for Treating Renal Colic Pain in the Emergency Department: A Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Hypothesis: Intravenous administration of Ketorolac 10 mg and 20 mg is as effective as 30 mg in treating renal colic pain in patients presenting to the emergency department

detailed_description.textblock: Ketorolac is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that is widely used in the Emergency Department (ED). Because of the Ketorolac significant analgesic potency, it is usually used for moderate-to-severe pain. However, ketorolac has several side effects, of which gastrointestinal hemorrhage is most concerning. "Analgesic ceiling" is defined as the dose beyond which no additional analgesia can be achieved and on the other hand, more side effects might be encountered. Several studies suggested 10 mg as analgesic ceiling. Despite this, many recommendations are still advocating several folds higher doses (e.g. 30, 60 mg).

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Pain assessed with visual analogue scale (VAS)
primary_outcome.description: The visual analogue scale (VAS) will be used for the study. The VAS ranges from 0 (no pain) to 100 (very severe pain). The higher the pain scores the higher the pain severity.

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain assessed with visual analogue scale (VAS)
secondary_outcome.description: The visual analogue scale (VAS) will be used for the study. The VAS ranges from 0 (no pain) to 100 (very severe pain). The higher the pain scores the higher the pain severity.

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain assessed with visual analogue scale (VAS)
secondary_outcome.description: The visual analogue scale (VAS) will be used for the study. The VAS ranges from 0 (no pain) to 100 (very severe pain). The higher the pain scores the higher the pain severity.

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain assessed with visual analogue scale (VAS)
secondary_outcome.description: The visual analogue scale (VAS) will be used for the study. The VAS ranges from 0 (no pain) to 100 (very severe pain). The higher the pain scores the higher the pain severity.
Dizziness (Adverse Effect), Nausea (Adverse Effect), Vomiting (Adverse Effect), headache (Adverse Effect)

arm_group.description: Subjects will be administered 10 mg of Ketorolac.
Subjects will be administered 20 mg of Ketorolac
As a part of standard care, subjects will be administered 30 mg of Ketorolac.

intervention.description: Subject will receive 10, 20, and 30mg of Ketorolac.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Severe flank and abdominal pain which pertains to renal colic according to emergency physician's gestalt
Exclusion Criteria:
- Age >65
- Active Peptic Ulcer disease
- Acute Gastrointestinal Hemorrhage
- Known History of Renal or Hepatic insufficiency
- History of allergies to NSAIDs
